resources:
Reserve Bank of Malawi
Info This sample needs camera permission. This device doesn\'t support Camera2 API. NN:On NN:Off Use NNAPI tflite NNAPI Threads:
Model:
Quantized
Float
Device:
CPU
GPU
NNAPI
LEAD (Holographic Foil Stripe) This is shiny near the left front edge of the banknote. When the bank note is tilted, the stripe shows the portrait of Rev. John Chilembwe, denomination value of 2000. The Reserve Bank of Malawi logo and the text "RESERVE BANK OF MALAWI."
Spark Live (Fish Shaped) This is an image of a fish that delivers colour changing properties and dynamic light effects. The image is located at the front of the banknote on the right side.
Watermark When the note is viewed against direct light, the watermark in form of the portrait and the denomination number as a highlight can be seen.
Intaglio Printing Intaglio printing is used on specific areas of the banknote. The intaglio print feels raised and rough, quite unlike the other sections of the note, which are smooth. The portrait, the denomination values, the RBM building and capital letters reading "RESERVE BANK OF MALAWI" are printed in the intaglio.
MicroPrint / Micro Text Small letters, numbers and /or images that are barely perceptible with the naked eye, but become visible at low magnification (under a loupe). ' Security Thread The security thread is a metallic-looking strip which is seen in small "windows". It is positioned on the reverse side in the center of the note. When the note is held against the light, the thread is seen as continuous dark line reading "RBM" and the denomination number in small letters.
LEAD (Holographic Foil Stripe) A holographic foil stripe is positioned at the right-hand side on the front. It shows the portrait as well as the bank logo and denomination number by tilting the banknote. Additionally the foil shows fine demetallisation areas in the upper and lower part and the text "RESERVE BANK OF MALAWI" and the denomination number which can be verified by holding the note against the light.
STEP (Color-Changing Ink) The denomination value on the upper left-hand side is printed with a color changing ink. When the note is tilted the color changes from green to blue.
Security Thread RollingStar Wave The security thread shows a dynamic wave travelling from the left to the right side and changing its color from green to blue upon tilting.
Security Thread RollingStar Cude The security thread created by counter-running cubes placed vertically near the center at the back of the note. The line changes color from gold to green when the note is tilted.
